sub_topic: Determining the rank of a matrix
message_1:
Find the rank of the following 3x3 matrix:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 & -1 \\ 3 & 4 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$$
message_2:
To find the rank of the matrix, we need to perform Gaussian elimination to get it into row-echelon form and then count the number of non-zero rows.

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 & -1 \\ 3 & 4 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$$

First, we can subtract 2 times the first row from the second row and 3 times the first row from the third row:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 & -7 \\ 0 & -2 & -8 \end{pmatrix}$$

Next, we can multiply the second row by -1 to make the leading entry positive:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 7 \\ 0 & -2 & -8 \end{pmatrix}$$

Now, we can add 2 times the second row to the third row:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 7 \\ 0 & 0 & 6 \end{pmatrix}$$

The matrix is now in row-echelon form, and we can see that all rows are non-zero. Therefore, the rank of the matrix is 3.
